bibl.title: Report: Anopheles and Malarial Fever Survey on and within (3) Miles of the Pond of Stevens Creek Dam on Savannah River, Columbia County, Georgia, by T.H.D. Griffitts, [1916]

div1.p: Griffitts describes a house-to-house search to determine the number and type of mosquitoes, as well as the number of people stricken with malaria.

div1.head: Report: Anopheles and Malarial Fever Survey on and within (3) Miles of the Pond of Stevens Creek Dam on Savannah River, Columbia County, Georgia, by T.H.D. Griffitts, [1916]
div1.p:
Jm. Water
S. Creek

REPORT ON ANOPHELES AND MALARIAL FEVER
SURVEY ON AND WITHIN (3) MILES OF THE POND OF STEVENS
CREEK DAM ON SAVANNAH RIVER, COLUMBIA COUNTY, GEORGIA.
BY
T. H. D. GRIFFITTS, M.D.
C.W. Davidson.

September 21, 1916, made survey on property of Mr. C.W.
Davidson, located on Washington road and approximately, it is
estimated, two miles from the nearest point of back water on
the Savannah River pond or of its afluent streams. Mrs. David-
son stated that the family (12 members now) has lived here for
13 years; three members (children) have had chills this year.
Beginning at 8:50 A.M. and spending 15 minutes (two persons)
in a search for Anopheles (a) in the house occupied by the
Davidson family (nearly all the time spent in the three bed-
rooms - these the most favorable places), no Anopheles mosqui-
toes were found. (b) Under the house, where physical conditions
were favorable, no Anopheles were found. (c) The horse and mule
barn (log 14 stalls), no Anopheles, (d) another mule and calf
stable, negative for Anopheles. (e) In a shed where chickens
stay, caught five Anopheles punctipennis; (f) in the feed room
adjoining the chicken shed, caught four (4) Anopheles puncti-
pennis; (g) in the privy caught two (2) Anopheles punctipennis.
An examination of the other houses or buildings on the premises
of Mr. Davidson showed them to be negative as to Anopheles in-
festation. These were:

1.- Cotton house, negative.
2.- Chicken house, "
3.- Pea house, "

The time spent in the examination of Mr. Davidson's res-
idence and out-buildings to determine the presence or absence of
malaria bearing mosquitoes was one (1) hour for two persons. The
(2)
foregoing record shows, no Anopheles in the house and eleven (11)
-Anopheles punctipennis-in or about the rest of the premises. No
other species of Anopheles found here. It was stated by Mrs. David-
son that mosquitoes at night were more “troublesome” on the porches
than in the house.
Breeding Places.

(a) There is a series of woodside pools (more or less tempo-
rary in character), approximately 250 yards towards Augusta from
Mr. Davidson's house, that I examined and found to be breeding both
Culex and Anopheles. The Anopheles larvae found here were mostly
small, although there were a few of about full size- almost to the
stage of becoming pupae. (b) The branch crossing the Washington
road near Mt. Enon Colored Church (Augusta side) was examined North
of the road where it runs through the pasture fields, and Anopheles
larvae of all sizes were found in the portions where current was
slight and there was overhanging grass and other protection for lar-
vae and pupae. (c) In a marshy area, covering in all about 1/4 acre,
and located about 150 yards Southwest of Mt. Enon Church, Anopheles
larvae (all sizes) and pupae were found. This is an out crop of
water at the toe of the hill, and from appearances is never dry,
but a constant Anopheles breeding place throughout the season.
Washing rains would not cause an overflow or scouring of area. From
an old hollow gum tree, five (5) feet from small collections of
water, from which Anopheles larvae were dipped, I caught twelve (12)
Anopheles punctipennis and one (1) Anopheles quadrimaculatus. The X
(d) The Baptismal pool and adjacent branch, 150 feet from the Mt.
Enon Church is breeding Anopheles mosquitoes. From these places
(3)
I dipped Anopheles larvae of all sizes and pupae. In a privy close
by I caught two (2) Anopheles punctipennis.
L.A. Kelley.

(On Mrs. Georgia Kelley's Place) North side of Wood road from
Davidson's); six members of the family stated they “have had
chills since the dam was made.” Here nine years and “most of us
had chills.” (a) I made a thorough search of the house (2 P.M.)
and found no Anopheles. It was stated that “mosquitoes are espec-
ially bad about the cow lot at milking time in evenings” and “a-
round the house after dark.” (b) An examination of the barn (used
jointly by L.A. and John Kelley and about half way between the two
houses) gave negative results for presence of Anopheles. (c) In bed
rooms of John Kelley's (Mrs. Georgia Kelley) house, caught two (2)
Anopheles punctipennis; (d) Chicken house, negative; (e) under crib
caught twenty-one (21) Anopheles punctipennis and one (1) Anopheles
quadrimaculatus. One hour's time was spent at the Kelley places.
No search was made for breeding places near the premises.
Lucy Hampton.

Colored, on Phoebia Porter Place. (a) This woman stated that
mosquitoes were very annoying, or “bad” about the house. Fifteen min-
utes'time (2 persons) were spent on inspection in this small house,
and no Anopheles were found. Caught two (2) Culex. I asked to see
the water barrel. It was at the side of the house and within three
feet of the door and was “teeming” with Culex larvae and pupae and
rafts of Culex eggs. I called the woman's attention to this and
demonstrated the use of kerosene to prevent mosquito development.
The Culex breeding barrel, in all probability, is the source of the
(4)
mosquito pest at this house. I judge that Lucy Hampton's house
is about 3/4 mile from back water of Betty's Branch (said to be
the nearest point of back water) (b) Breeding: In swampy area
about spring near Lucy Hampton's cabin, I dipped several Anopheles
larvae. These were small to three quarter grown and none kept for
further development. This area is said to be on the Dr. Phinizy
plantation.
Impounded Water-

Betty's Branch: This was the first place examined on the pond
of the Steven's Creek dam. The physical conditions appeared good
for Anopheles breeding. At the point touched*, the water was shallow,
varying from six inches to practically nothing, the bottom muddy,
Cat-tails, growing and dead, overfallen bulrushes and, generally,
collections of fine floatage against them. In the area examined-
about 20 square feet- there were collected in one-half hour's time
(two persons dipping) about one hundred (100) large Anopheles lar-
vae and twelve (12) to fifteen (15) pupae. There were Anopheles
larvae here of all sizes. Apparently there were no top feeding min-
nows here, although they were acting in fair numbers two hundred
yards higher up in Betty's branch. (The breeding place above re-
ferred to is 40 minutes' walk from L.A. Kelley's house, and 50
- 2 miles!
minutes from C.W. Davidson's.) - 2+ miles!
“Willie” Seymour-

Colored - Old Sneed place; seven in the family; here two
years and they say all had “chills” last year, and all again this
year. This house is located approximately 1/3 of a mile S.W. of
the place mentioned in Paragraph 4*. Spent fifteen minutes (2 per-
sons) in examining the house. In the house, caught thirteen (13)
(5)
Anopheles quadrimaculatus and one (1) Anopheles punctipennis. It was
late in the evening and lack of time prevented examination of the
entire premises.
M. I. Gray:

(On Washington road, Sept. 22) There are 10 persons living at
this house and three have had “chills” this year, it is said. (a)
The four bed rooms were thoroughly examined for Anopheles. In the
N.E. room, caught three (3) Anopheles quadrimaculatus. These were all
that were found in the house. (b) Barn with six horse stalls (appar-
ently good resting place for mosquitoes), caught one (1) Anopheles
punctipennis; (c) wagon shed and cow stalls - 50 feet from horse barn
caught twelve (12) Anopheles punctipennis; (d) chicken house, cotton
and carriage houses, all negative; (e) buggy shed. one (1) Anopheles
punctipennis.
Breeding Places:

(a) Southwest of M.I. Gray's house, 1400 feet and 225 to 500
feet from Gray's S. line in a pasture field, is a series of wet areas,
hoof prints, small pools and ditches, most of which contained Anophe-
les larvae. In some they were numerous, particularly small ones. These
out-croppings from the hill are more or less permanent and continuous
breeding places, judging from the physical appearances. They are on
the water shed of Betty's Branch. A good collection of Anopheles lar-
vae was made here. (b) From this point, I followed the course of
Betty's Branch down to the Washington road and no places physically
suited for breeding was encountered, although minute examination
was not made, for lack of time. (c) A marshy area 200 yards, South of
the store at Gray's. The water in most of this wet area is covered at
this time with “ground oil”, but in three or four hoof prints Anopheles
(6)
larvae were found. This, I think, would become an important
breeding place in a wet season.
Earl Jackson.-

Colored, living in old Stein house N.E.(?) of Gray's and a few
hundred feet from the breeding place noted above. Careful search made
in the (a) bedrooms and one (1) Anopheles quadrimaculatus found; (b)
under house, negative.
Ishman Williams-

Colored, three in family, near Earl Jackson's and on the old
Stein place, negative.
Henry Williams-

Colored, (on Mrs. Sarah Griffins place, 1st cabin West of
gin) There are eight in the family, have lived here one year, no
history of malaria - mosquitoes do not trouble them (a) No Anophe-
les found in house; (b) none in barn, cotton house, sheds, etc.
Jims Holmes-

Colored, (Capt. (Armstrong's place) There are three in the
family; have lived in this immediate vicinity for five years; no history of
malaria. The woman said mosquitoes were bad in the house at nights-
“smudged” them out. No Anopheles were found in the house, found two
dead Culex in cob-webs.
John Thompkins-

Mrs. Sarah Griffin's place. Nine in family, moved here Dec-
ember 1915, coming here from near Mt. Hope. Had chills last year,
but none this year, (a) In the house I caught one (1) Anopheles
punctipennis; (b) barn, negative.
Andrew Vincent-

Colored, (Old Stein place) Reported mosquitoes are bad- No
history of chills. House not examined.
Louis Gibert-

Old Sneed place. Here one year, last year at Mrs. Sarah
Griffin's old home place. History of chills this year and last
year. (a) In the house found three (3) Anopheles quadrimaculatus
and one (1) Anopheles punctipennis.
Joe Jones-

Colored - Old Sneed place; two in family, here four months,
had first chill (wife) two weeks ago; the husband had “chill” in
August. (a) House, negative for Anopheles.
Evans Johnson-

Colored, Old Sneed place; nine in family, here one year;
“seven have had chills this year” and "three or four had chills
last year at Allen's station. In the house, caught five (5)
Anopheles quadrimaculatus and one (1) Anopheles punctipennis
James L. Johnson-

Sept. 23. Colored, one-half mile West of Walton's Island and
the same distance South of Little Kiokee Creek. The Johnson's have
lived here twenty years; six in the family and he (Johnson) had
“chills” here in 1903. Doesn't “remember having chills since that
time.” (a) In the house (one person collecting for fifteen minutes)
caught eleven (11) Anopheles quadrimaculatus and two (2) Anopheles
punctipennis; (b) Barn, four (4) Anopheles quadrimaculatus; (c)
Colt stable, fourteen (14) Anopheles quadrimaculatus and two Anophe-
; (1) (d) Anopheles punctipennis (2) -
In a marshy area and small pools about 300 yards S.W. of James L.
Johnson's house Anopheles are breeding freely - rather profusely.
Collected here in about fifteen minutes time (2 personel about
(8)
fifty (50) largen Anopheles larvae and a dozen pupae. This place
is about 100 feet from “old gum spring” on Mrs. Clanton's (?) prop-
erty. Below the gum spring and among water lillies, dipped from one-
half dozen to two dozen Anopheles larvae a dip. Owing to lack of
time this area was not examined further.
Little Kiokee Creek:

Three-fourth mile N. of James L. Johnson's. There are flat
mud banks, much overfallen trees and loge, no green vegetation along
water line. Examining for a distance of 100 yards, found no Anophe-
les larvae, but many top feeding minnows (Gambusia affinis) At this
place there is no floatage or debris for larvae protection and the
top minnows are apparently controlling. (On September 25; this por-
tion of the creek, as well as the part below to the mouth, was exam-
ined from a row boat and away from the banks. Here, breeding of
sanitary importance is taking place. A rather large amount of small
drift (also logs) and fine and leaf floatage was found and larvae
could be taken at each dip. Here they were protected from the attacks
of minnows.
Big Kiokee Creek;

September 25. For a distance of about 3/4 mile up from the
former mouth of this creek, examined from a rowboat, Anopheles
are breeding, here profusely. There is a great deal of fine float-
age and leaf floatage collected against small branches, overhanging
canes, fallen dead vegetation, logs, etc., and every dip made about
such places collected Anopheles larvae - all sizes - and pupae.
some dips brought as many as two dozen Anopheles larvae and pupae.
This body of water for the 3/4 (lower) mile examined is breeding
Anopheles profusely. The back water in this creek is said to extend
(109)
for a distance of two miles from its former mouth, but time did
not permit of more extended survey

Raft of logs 1/4 mile below upper point of Walton Island,
forming the beginning of a floating island, found no Anopheles
larvae. (b) Raft in little river 100 yards above the lower point
of Walton Island - no Anopheles larvae found. (c) Raft below old
sawmill and shore line to Fury's ferry, only about 1/2 dozen
(small) Anopheles larvae found. Top feeding minnows noted. (d)
Shore Line of Kent Philpot's place. The banks are flat and clean
(bare) except for a very few leafless tree tops; Gambusia affinis
(minnows) are numerous, and seem to be controlling, Only about
1/2 dozen Anopheles larvae dipped and half of these came from an
area of seepage outcrop near the lake but not dependent upon it.
(Here I would direct your attention to the growth of so-called
“silver grass” growing in the marshy area. This grass gaining a
foot-hold in a pond becomes an important factor in mosquito breed-
ing, furnishing protection from the fish that are destructive to
larvae) (So far none seems to have extended to the pond). (e) The
shore from the Philpot place to within one mile of the dam was
examined at intervals and no Anopheles breeding of sanitary importance
was noted.

Record of development of mosquitoes from the larvae
collected.

1. Roadside pools, and other places (near Mt. Enon
Church, on Davidson property-
Anopheles punctipennis.......8
" quadrimaculatus....0
2. Baptismal Pool (at Mt. Enon Church) -
Anopheles punctipennis......13
" quadrimaculatus .. 0
3. About mouth Betty's Branch- Water of Savannah Pond.
Anopheles punctipennis.......1
" quadrimaculatus...16
4. Pasture Pools and Seepage out-crops Gray's pasture.
Anopheles punctipennis...... 5
" quadrimaculatus... 0
5. Pools and marsh near James L. Johnson-
Anopheles punctipennis......15
" quadrimaculatus... 0
6. Main Pond the Kiokee Creeks-
Anopheles punctiennis........4
" quadrimaculatus ...0

Griffitts
x
Columbia a Co. Ga
(Stevens Creek Pond
